IRS990.ActivityOrMissionDescription: America's largest civil rights organization working to achieve LGBT equality
IRS990.MissionDescription: The Human Rights Campaign is America's largest civil rights organization working to achieve lesbian,gay, bisexual and transgender equality. By inspiring and engaging all Americans, HRC strives to end discrimination against LGBT citizens and realize a nation that achieves fundamental fairness and equality for all.
IRS990.Description: FEDERAL, FIELD AND LEGAL ADVOCACY: HRC ENGAGED MORE PEOPLE THAN EVER TO MEET WITH LAWMAKERS AND TO DEMAND ACTION ON THE ISSUES THAT AFFECT LGBT AMERICANS. AFTER HRC'S CALL TO ACTION IN 2009, CONGRESS PASSED THE HISTORIC MATTHEW SHEPARD AND JAMES BYRD, JR. HATE CRIMES PROTECTION ACT - AFTER MORE THAN 10 YEARS OF EFFORT. HRC CONTINUED BROAD-BASED EFFORTS TO BUILD SUPPORT FOR A FULLY-INCLUSIVE ENDA BY CREATING THE BUSINESS COALITION FOR WORKPLACE FAIRNESS, HOSTING 300 CLERGY MEMBERS IN WASHINGTON, DC FOR CONGRESSIONAL LOBBYING, COORDINATING IN-DISTRICT LOBBYING BY 1,000 HRC MEMBERS, AND EDUCATING AND TRAINING FAITH COMMUNITIES ABOUT GENDER IDENTITY ISSUES IN PRIORITY DISTRICTS. REPEAL OF "DON'T ASK DON'T TELL" WAS ANOTHER PRIORITY WITH THE "VOICES OF HONOR" TOUR FEATURING LGBT AND STRAIGHT VETERANS TELLING THEIR STORIES AND SPEAKING OUT AGAINST DADT AT OVER 30 EVENTS IN KEY STATES, FOCUSED AND INTENSIVE GRASSROOTS ACTIVITY IN SIX KEY STATES, AND BROAD-BASED ADVOCACY ACROSS THE COUNTRY.

Activity2.Description: Public Policy, Education & Training: HRC worked to build understanding and awareness of the LGBT community by telling our stories to the American public through the mainstream press. HRC also maintains a presence in the LGBT media to help educate, inform and engage our community. HRC worked to share our stories through our website www.hrc.org, our publications, including Equality magazine, and a variety of online outlets such as our award-winning videos and our blog, HRC Back Story.

Activity3.Description: Membership Education and Mobilization: HRC has more than 750,000 members and supporters. Membership education and mobilization consists of informing members about legislative issues as well as current events and other issues that impact the LGBT community.

Form990ScheduleCPartIV.ReturnReference: Organizations Direct and Indirect Political Campaign Activities:
Form990ScheduleCPartIV.Explanation: HRC communicated with its membership about federal and state elections in 2009 and in support of endorsed fair-minded candidates. HRC paid the administrative expenses of HRC PAC, HRC's federal political action committee, and state PACs where permitted by law.

OtherAssets.Description: due from related organizations & HRC Foundation

Form990ScheduleDPartXIV.ReturnReference: Description of Uncertain Tax Positions Under FIN 48:
Form990ScheduleDPartXIV.Explanation: In June 2006, the Financial Accounting Standards Board (FASB) released FASB ASC 740 10, Income Taxes, that provides guidance for reporting uncertainty in income taxes. For the year-ended March 31, 2010, HRC and the Foundation have documented their consideration of FASB ASC 740-10 and determined that no material uncertain tax positions qualify for either recognition or disclosure in the combined financial statements.

Form990ScheduleIPartIV.Identifier: Procedure for Monitoring Grants in the U.S.:
Form990ScheduleIPartIV.Explanation: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2: HRC field staff are in regular contact with organizations receiving contributions or other assistance from HRC. HRC staff provide strategic advice to contribution recipients and work with them before and after financial support is provided to develop plans consistent with HRC's mission in support of lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender equal rights. All contributions and recipients are reviewed in advance by HRC's general counsel. Expenditures by ballot measure committee recipients are disclosed pursuant to state or local law and periodically reviewed by HRC's general counsel.

Form990ScheduleJPartIII.Explanation: HRC provided first class air travel on occasion for President Joe Solmonese, as permitted by policy adopted by the HRC Board. The president's schedule often requires last minute changes in travel plans, and therefore fully refundable tickets are frequently used. First class tickets were occasionally purchased in situations in which fully refundable coach tickets were comparably priced to first class tickets.

THE HUMAN RIGHTS CAMPAIGN (HRC) AND HUMAN RIGHTS CAMPAIGN FOUNDATION(HRCF) HAVE ENTERED INTO A COST SHARING ARRANGEMENT UNDER WHICH HRCF REIMBURSES HRC FOR HRCF'S ALLOCABLE SHARE OF THE COMPENSATION OF CERTAIN HRC EMPLOYEES. PURSUANT TO THIS AGREEMENT, HRCF REIMBURSED HRC FOR THE FOLLOWING PORTION OF TOTAL COMPENSATION PAID BY HRC AS FOLLOWS: JOSEPH SOLMONESE (OFFICER) 32,541 SUSANNE SALKIND (OFFICER) 12,714 JAMES RINEFIERD (OFFICER) 41,694 ROBERT FALK (OFFICER) 37,262 ELIZABETH PURSELL(OFFICER) 150,230 ANDREA GREEN (FORMER OFFICER) 33,038

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section A, line 1
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: Under the HRC bylaws, the Executive Committee "shall meet as needed and on an emergency basis and shall exercise, between Board Meetings, all the powers and duties of the Board, except the election of Directors to fill vacancies on the Board, the removal of Directors from the Board, and the amendment of the By-Laws." The bylaws provide that The Co-Chairs of the board appoint the Executive Committee,"which shall include the Co-Chairs of the Board of Directors, the Co-Chairs of the Board of Governors, the Co-Chairs of each Board Committee and up to four (4) members at large. During the operating years of a strategic planning process, the Executive Committee shall include the Co-Chairs of that Committee. The Co-Chairs may also appoint task force or special project chair(s) to serve on the Executive Committee for the duration of their assignments." Under these provisions, all members of the Executive Committee must be members of the board.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, line 11
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: The form 990 is prepared by the outside accountants and is reviewed by senior management. the audit and finance committees review the 990 prior to filing. A copy is provided electronically to all board members before the 990 is filed.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, line 12c
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: The organization annually sends out to its officers and directors the conflicts of interest policy and requests a signed disclosure form from each covered individual. Any disclosed conflict is reviewed by the general counsel. If a conflict does exist on a specific issue, meeting minutes would reflect the board action taken to clear the conflict, either by having the affected board member or officer recuse themselves from the discussion or vote or remove themselves from all deliberations.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, line 15
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: In 2009, prior to the start of the new fiscal year, the board appointed a committee of independent directors to look at the president's compensation before his contract was renewed. In reviewing compensation, the committee reviewed salary surveys of comparable non-profit organizations in the Washington DC area and data available from the 990s of other comparable non-profits. The committee deliberated independently of the president and minutes of that meeting were taken and ratified by the committee. The committee's findings were presented to the full board, which adopted its findings in March of 2009. The same committee that examined the president's compensation also looked at the current compensation of the organization's officers and key employees. The same set of materials and procedures were used to assess the compensation of the officers and key employees, and minutes were kept of the meeting. The findings were presented to the full board, which adopted its findings in March of 2009. Based on that review, the Board approved a two year contract for the president. As a result of changes in the economy, all compensation for other officers and key employees was frozen in FY 2010. Consequently, the organization believes that the 2009 analysis remains applicable in 2010.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section C, line 19
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: No documents available to the public.
